21098263.review:
A game I had a lot of fun with, but it has quite a bit of flaws. Having never played a Shantae and hearing it was a metroidvania style game, I was dissapointed when it turned out to be a mostly linear 2d zelda affair. The backtracking, unlike in regular metroidvania which makes exploring the world and unlocking new paths exciting and lore-richening, seemed like a tedious chore in this game. Almost like filler that they had to do in order for the game to be just a bit longer. The good thing is that the fast travel things you can buy in the one shop (yeah unfortunately there's only one shop in the very paltry main city) in this game are cheap.

Now some positives. The game plays and looks well, for the most part. The animations, music, and overall style of the game are on point. Usually I find that when a game panders towards an audience it is bad. At a cursory glance one look at Shantae almost looks like its pandering toward that harem big boobied fetish, and there's no denying that it is. Since the game is so tongue and cheek about the whole thing, and Shantae's dialogue is genuinely that of a cute character, I am down with it. It's not one of those visual novels that wants you to fap every second, the big boobs are there to be enjoyed in the background and in this case work as a fine character trait.

The dungeons, although entirely linear, had great platforming. Some rooms have you dying over and over to reach the goal, which I found quite challenging and awesome. The game starts out pretty easy, but about halfway through there is a major difficulty spike. Each and every boss in the game was excellently animated and a thrill to fight. All of the upgrades of the game got better and better, and by the end I truly felt like an OP character. This is how upgrades should be done, with each upgrade being a standalone good weapon, but also synergizing with the previous upgrades aquired. 

And since this review, although I liked the game, pointed out some flaws let me just point out one small thing that annoyed me to heck. It doesn't affect the gameplay, it doesn't affect the enjoyment, it's just that when the score and the graphics and the gameplay and everything else has such high production value why does the pause menu look so crappy? Like they used they paintbucket tool on the regular blue setting and called it a day. I know pause menu's aren't the most exciting part of a game, but it always looked out of place.

Well anyway, despite the shortcomings and filler the game was cool. I'll pick up the next Shantae game if it's cheap and if it ever comes out. (At the time of this review the game has been in kickstarter hell for quite a bit of time.)

21062361.review:
This is pretty much an improvement over Risky's Revenge in about every way. It's longer, more balanced, faster-paced, and in general just more fun to play. Though I'd also say it's still far from a perfect game.

A few things to note right off the bat; while this does have a metroidvania-style powerup system and shop and all that, the game map is divided up strictly into levels, each level being decently sized, but yeah there's no interconnected map here. The game does have an actual map system though, something that was sorely missing from Risky's Revenge. And as well you'll easily know when you've collected everything in an area since it shows on the world map.

The main game mechanics, Risky's various items, are much more fun than the dancing of the rest of the series. No more slowing to a crawl to perform a dance that's mostly only useful in a few select areas, this time you can pull any of your tools out at a whim and practically every one of them has uses both in platforming and in combat.

The pistol is, well, a pistol. You're gonna be using it for ranged attacks a lot, and though it's fairly weak compared to other weapons it's still plenty useful. The hat is mainly used for platforming purposes to glide through the air, but it's pretty solid. I do think it should pull out faster, there were a lot of points where I felt it was a struggle to use because of how slow it is to pull out (especially in one spot in the last dungeon that's waaay harder than it should be). The scimitar lets you bounce on enemies as well as break floor tiles below you, though you have almost no horizontal movement when using it, which would've been nice and allowed for some clever puzzles, but oh well. The boots are possibly the most fun item, letting you charge rampantly through everything, zoom zoom plowing through enemies, it's so much fun. Wish it was mapped to a button rather than to a context-sensitive timer, but it'd probably be horribly broken otherwise, I suppose. And the cannon gives you three extra jumps AND another aerial attack, allowing for safer fighting and pretty much breaking all the jumping puzzles in the game.

The icing on the cake is the mode you unlock after clearing the game for the first time that allows you to play through the game with all the tools from the start, speeding up the game quite a bit and allowing for some -fun- strategies against earlier bosses.

The bosses, then, let's talk about them. They're... a mixed bag. I like some of them, while some others are a bit... bad. The boss of the fifth island, for one, misleads you into thinking you should be fighting it with the gun since that's the most convenient weapon to use, but that is definitely NOT the weapon you actually want to use, you want to hair-whip it to pull it down to the ground, and... eh... I really don't like that boss because of the bad first impression it left on me. The boss on the sixth island is relatively easy, sure, but annoying since it's literally RNG and little else. I'm not really a fan of the movement RNG in these bosses in general, the third island boss, fourth island boss, and first phase of the final boss have it the worst in this regard, though maybe it's because I had to spend time grinding to no-damage kill these bosses, but it's a minor gripe. Overall the bosses are more good than bad though, in the end.

The enemies and combat in general are also pretty solid, there's a few that annoy, a few too tanky, a few too powerful, and the first area of the fifth island is just a huge pain because of rampant enemy spam, but in general it's balanced well with the platforming. There's a fair number of enemies back from Risky's Revenge, but plenty of new ones thrown into the mix as well. The platforming is also generally pretty interesting and creative, as are the few puzzles scattered throughout the maps. The exploration elements are there, too, even with the map designs, though some parts play out almost like an adventure game, trying to figure out where to go next or finding a specific item you need to progress the story, but poking around older areas with new tools tends to produce results most of the time. It's a very solid, enjoyable experience on the whole.

The game also looks great, the spritework and animations are lovely, the level graphics and background graphics are all nice, the character portraits look great. The game also sounds great, there's some reused music from Risky's Revenge but a lot of the original tracks are just generally nice and never really wear out, plus it helps that there's quite a ton of music in the game in general, 2-3 map tracks per island, multiple cutscene themes, a few boss themes, really no shortage of good tunes.

It's really hard to fault this game much, I had a few gripes with it but nothing that adds up to a major problem, and most importantly, it's fun. That's all I really need a game to be, in the end.

20985750.review: One of the BEST series out there. Wayforward creates some of the best games, Shantae being an OUTSTANDING Metroidvania.

20979040.review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a classic 2D action platformer with metroidvania elements. However, compared to most generic modern platformers, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse distinguishes itself by the highest level of quality, with WayForward's pedigree in game development clearly visible throughout the whole game. Actually, this game is a part of an established series, being the third and latest installment to date.

The first thing you'll notice is the overall quality of graphics and animation, with the game being mostly done in awesome high-quality pixel art. Shantae also takes advantage of modern platforms by using high-resolution character sprites for dialogue segments. Everything looks even better in motion — the animations are surprisingly detailed and very smooth, so the fact that there are a lot of them in the game is a cherry on top. Shantae and the Pirate's Curse combines regual 2D pixel-art and modern visual effects, which look together better than you'd think. The game runs at 60 FPS, like platformers used to, and actually, should be played. Super smooth animations and super precise movement — eye candy and a soothing experience where the character moves exactly like you want them to.

Music and sound effects in Shantae and the Pirate's Curse don't fall short of the graphics, with the game featuring a large number of high quality and atmospheric music tracks, which greatly fit not only the overall game, but individual levels and characters as well. And since we're on the topic of levels, it should be mentioned that level design in Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is great, both in terms of visuals and platforming. It's clear that developers at WayForward are masters of old school platforming, employing challenging and interesting design, traps, secrets and everything else that makes this game feel like such classics as Megaman.

Every world in the game (seven in total) not only has its own visual theme and music, but is also designed around different types of platforming that you'll need to employ. Some levels feature platforming that is heavily influenced by games such as Megaman, while metroidvania elements present themselves mainly through the world being a bunch of inter-connected locations, presence of hidden areas and new locations slowly becoming accessible with new item acquisition.

Unlike previous games in the series, where Shantae used her magic, this time you're faced with the fact that she lost it (in the previous game), so she must overcome the challenges with various items that she'll come across through the game. Usually in a game like this items would be for unlocking / adding abilites, and weapons would be used for fighting, but in Shantae even weapons unlock new abilities to the player.    

The game world consists of different islands that are unlocked after completing boss fights. These boss fights aren't that difficult, especially if you stock up on healing items, but fun nonetheless. Bosses are very large, and have a cool design, which comes in variety - a huge-ass tank straight outta Metal Slug, a misspelled fire-breathing monstrosity Dagron, and of course, an abomination to your screen space in form of the final boss (true form only).

To sum it up, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a joy to play, not only because of visuals and sound, but stellar level design and gameplay. An interesting cute protagonist also helps. For some reason people mostly missed out on this gem, with SteamSpy estimating sales at ~25K. But you definitely should buy and play this game, even if you aren't a fan of the genre.

P.S. For more awesome hidden gems, follow the [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10722089/]CRIMINALLY Low Sales[/url] steam curator.

20531143.review:
wayforwardから発売された、shantaeシリーズ第3弾。
初期作は残念ながらGBなのでsteamにはありませんが、この作品単体でも充分に満足できる内容となっております

話の内容としては、主人公shantaeと前作の敵Riskyが共闘してさらに大きな敵と戦う、という王道展開です
操作できるのは、前作同様shantaeだけですが
なぜRiskyと敵対していたか気になる人は、前作を買ってみるのもありかもしれません

ゲーム自体としては、とてもとっつきやすいメトロイドヴァニアのACTでしょうか
開発元のwayforwardがかなり日本に影響されているらしく、イラストレイターは日本人を起用していたり、謎解き要素などは有名なゼルダシリーズやメトロイドを髣髴とさせるためすんなりとプレイできます
トレーラームービーは若干ネタバレが多いですが、本当にムービー通りの操作ができるため一度見てみると良いかもしれません

ゲーム自体の難易度もしっかりと考えて調整してあり、程々の難易度で楽しむことが出来ます
アクションが苦手な方も回復アイテムゴリ押しでほぼなんとかなるため、難易度で詰まるといったことはほぼ無いといっていいでしょう

気になる点としては、
・新しいアクションは基本ダンジョンでのアンロック式のため、最初のうちはあまり多彩なことができない
・お使いミッションではないが、新しい場所に行くために同じ場所を往復したり特定の人物を探すために走り回る必要がある
・steam版は日本語非対応のため、英語がわからないと誰をどこに探しに行けば良いのかわからなくなる
この辺りでしょうか

現在3DSで日本語版も発売されているので、英語が苦手な方はそちらを購入するのも一つの手ではあります
そこまで難しい英語でもないので、雰囲気で読み進めても特に問題はありませんが。

総評すれば、かなり質の高いACTゲーであり、定価の値段でも充分に元が取れる内容となっております
値引き自体もちょこちょこされていますので、ぜひ購入して遊んでみてはいかがでしょうか

20391772.review:
The original Shantae was difficult to enjoy due to the restrictions of the Gameboy's screen, forcing you to play with a very small field of view. Risky's Revenge had confusing maps and slow gameplay that eventually turned me away from it. 

But here we finally have what I can confidently call an excellent Shantae game. The gameplay is so much faster here and the world has been split up into different islands, making map navigation no longer an issue. And the music, man, I swear Jake Kaufman gets better with every album he releases. Rave in the Grave just blew my mind when I first heard it. It's so catchy. And I was really surprised when Scorching Dunes started out kinda generic, but then slowly evolved into a tune very reminiscent of the old Sonic games. And the tracks actually change a little bit on their second loop, keeping them from getting repetitive.

But of course, there are issues. The Monster Milk items, which greatly boost your attack power, make most boss fights utterly worthless. The only boss that I kinda enjoyed was the Steel Maggot, because it had mechanics that went beyond just using the item you got in that dungeon. You need a little bit of observation and trial and error to beat it.

Here's the problem with all of the Shantae games. Your most effective method of attack is a hair whip that can't be used while moving unless you're in the air. The devs then have to design the entire game based around that limitation. So levels are a lot of running, then stopping to attack, then running, so on and so forth. It's a lot like Castlevania Simon's Quest. Most regular enemies are no challenge and only serve to hinder your progress. (This is also why I appreciate the new pirate items so much. They let you speed through areas much more easily.) 

Bosses are pretty much the same. They all have periods where they just stand still and let you hit them repeatedly, which is required because of the limitation of Shantae's hair. It's a fault by design and should really be changed for the next game, Half-Genie Hero. I should never get to a final boss and not be intimidated. 

But hey, Wayforward isn't the biggest company out there. They did what they could and I think they did great. The art, the music, the characters, the humor, and the improved gameplay thanks to the pirate items make Shantae and the Pirate's Curse a memorable experience. I just hope that Half-Genie Hero doesn't squander the achievements made in this game and takes steps backwards.

20388507.review:
Ancora una volta Wayforward ci consegna un altro fantastico Shantae, questa volta più ampio e più divertente che mai!
è incredibile come Wayforward sia rimasta l'unica casa non indie (anche se si comporta da tale) che sappia produrre questo tipo di giochi. Il punto è che nel giocare questi giochi ci si aspetta di avere fra le mani un clone di Metroid o Castlevania (come il nome del genere ci suggerisce) ma Shantae è veramente qualcosa di diverso: non c'è nessun collegamento con queste due saghe e il gameplay, seppur ispiratissimo a questo tipo di giochi, dista ampiamente dalle saghe che hanno definito questo genere... ma andiamo per gradi!

(Saranno necessari richiami alla storia del capitolo precedente. Se non volete spoiler riguardo Shantae: Risky's Revenge evitate di leggere i primi 4 o 8 righi a seconda della visualizzazione)

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse è il terzo gioco di questa splendida saga. L'uso di Shantae è un po' diverso rispetto allo scorso capitolo, questa volta potrà contare solamente su abilità da umana visto che, il nostro mezzo genio, ha perso l'uso della magia nello scorso capitolo. Non ci saranno più danze del ventre e trasformazioni, stavolta Shantae potrà contare solamente sulle sue nuove armi da "umana" (nonchè i suoi splendidi capelli); il gameplay risulta dunque sia rinnovato che fedele ai capitoli precedenti. Le mappe sono decisamente più ampie rispetto al capitolo precedente e, nella forma, ricordano molto le mappe del primo gioco per Gameboy color (uscito alla fine del suo ciclo vitale, praticamente contemporaneo con il gameboy advance) infatti non sarà presente la navigazione su più livelli come in Risky's Revenge. In compenso, Shantae stavolta navigherà per diverse isole nel corso della sua avventura offrendo dunque al giocatore molta varietà e aumentando la longevità del gioco. Utilissima invece la nuova grafica per le mappe in perfetto stile Metroid/Castlevania dove saranno segnati i punti di salvataggio (in rosso per giunta), le entrate dei dungeons e i punti rilevanti. Saranno presenti inoltre molti riferimenti musicali dei giochi del passato insieme a moltissime canzoni nuove e ben composte. Rimossi i Magic Jars ma introdotti le magie nere, utili per completare il gioco al 100%, e i "Calamacuori" (stavolta il gioco è completamente tradotto) che, come i frammenti di cuore in Zelda, una volta collezionati quattro di questi e portati dalla porno fabbra (il fabbro femmina?) di Scuttle town, questa potrà aumentare di un'unità la nostra vita massima. Nessun sistema di level up è stato introdotto, Shantae dovrà ancora recarsi in negozio per comprare (più volte stavolta) shampoo e balsamo per aumentare la forza del suo attacco primario e gli upgrades delle sue nuove armi. Come al solito i personaggi sono molto spiritosi anche se, la totale traduzione del gioco, non coglie appieno lo humor velato della lingua originale (ho visto un paio di screenshot in inglese di alcune battute e devo dire che rendono poco in italiano). Tuttavia le battute riescono comunque a strappare molte risate e lo stile grafico, soprattutto dei bellissimi artwork a cura di Inti Creates, è semplicemente perfetto e decisamente superiore a Risky's Revenge. Come già accennato, il gioco è molto più grande rispetto al precedente ma questo, soprattutto nei primi livelli, risulta molto facilitato e se come me ci giocherete per più ore consecutivamente (per via magari di un'influenza che vi costringerà a letto) rischierete di finirlo molto in fretta! Qui però, in sostituzione della modalità magica del vecchio gioco, sarà possibile sbloccare la modalità pirata che consentirà a Shantae di tenere tutte le armi ottenibili nei dungeons sin dall'inizio, consentendo di completare il gioco nel minor tempo possibile (e poter sbloccare dunque gli altri sfondi del menù e forse dei finali alternativi).

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse è un gioco validissimo che merita di essere comprato ad occhi chiusi! Tanti i miglioramenti e tante le promesse per altri capitoli ancora più belli ed immersivi. Wayforward si supera ancora una volta, stavolta forse di poco, ma tanto quel che basta di poter parlare di miglioramenti e per rinfrescare una saga già fresca di suo! In mia opinione Shantae and the Pirate's Curse rialza veramente lo standard per questo stile di gioco (in attesa forse di Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night) ed è un action/platformer veramente eccezionale. Se siete amanti dello stile Metroidvania questo è un gioco che non vi deve assolutamente sfuggire! Altamente raccomandato! 

9.5/10

20241993.review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is the latest and most innovative game in the Shantae series so far. 
There's a lot I could say about this game but I'm just going to list off some Pro's and Con's.

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
- Amazing sprite art reminiscent of the 16-bit era
- Brilliant chiptune soundtrack by none other than Jake "Virt" Kaufman (Shovel Knight)
- Gameplay inspired by Castlevania and MegaMan respectively
- Humorous dialogue between characters.

[h1]Con's[/h1] 
- Difficulty ramps up quite suddenly toward the end
- Quite short for the price (Ranging from 10-15 hours)
- Controller is [b]Necessary[/b] for most people
- Lack of actual button prompts (For instance the game will tell you to press the "scimitar button" as opposed to the actual button on your controller/keyboard.

Do I recommend this game? Yes.
Does it have its faults? Sure.
Is it fun? You're god damn right.

20190411.review:
[h1]Shantae and the Pirate's Curse[/h1]

(Originally played this title on the Wii U)

Platform: PC Windows
Genre: 2D Sidescroller/Platformer/Metroidvania

[b]Introduction[/b]:

This is now the second game I've ever played where the protagonist is a female with her hair being her main power (The first one being Bayonetta). This installment in the main Shantae series from Way Forward Technology, just like the previous installments, offers much more than whipping your hair back and forth, Willow Smith style. A 2D platformer with a stunning soundtrack, Shantae and the pirate's curse is truly a blast to play and is arguably the best entry in the series.

[b]An uneasy alliance[/b]:

Shantae is a half genie girl, belly dancer, and the guardian of Scuttle Town. Following the events of Shantae: Riskys Revenge, Shantae has now lost her Genie powers, but instead gets to borrow some of her former nemesis Risky Boots weapons to get by. When the mayor of Scuttle town sells the town for some chocolate to the military madman Ammo Baron, Shantae is forced to spring into action. Bigger problems lies at hand though, as Risky Boots confronts Shantae about the impending return of the Pirate Master, an evil tyrant who was sealed away by the genies of Sequin Land long ago. They reluctantly choose to work together and weaken the dark powers across the land by visiting many different islands and defeating evil creatures to prevent the Pirate Masters return.

[b]Hair whipping & dungeon exploration[/b]:

Shantae's pony tail is something to be respected and it will be your main way of taking on the great variety of enemies that you will encounter. Whipping enemies as well as breakable pots makes gems drop which you can then use to upgrade your various items and said hair. Scuttle town acts as the hub town and you return there many times to buy shampoo for her hair, making your attack power go up and a silky cream which allows for faster whipping. A few damage upgrades are also available for new items that you will acquire as you progress through the story.

A 2D platformer with Metroidvania and The Legend of Zelda (Get item in dungeon, use said item on dungeon boss) style gameplay, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is certainly the best game yet in the Shantae series. Now that Shantae doesnt have to perform a dance (Although she is a very talented one) to transform herself into different animals but instead uses Risky Boots weapons and gear to get around, the pacing is a clear step up from previous titles. The dungeons are fun to explore and the platforming, while not being all that difficult, is still one of the best things about Shantae, mostly because of how perfectly precise the controls are. The dungeons also feature some thrilling boss fights at the end of each one, but I was a bit disappointed in the lack of difficulty and challenge most of them provided.

There are also Risky Boots army of small dark creatures called Tinkerbats that have been possessed by the Pirate Master's dark magic that Shantae can find in various locations. You can also find heart squids throughout the game that will increase your overall health. Just like in any Zelda game, trying to find all of these isn't all that compelling, with the somewhat lack of challenge that the game overall provides, but a few tricky platform sections and the latter part of the game will surely cause some unexpected deaths. The game lasted me about 10 hours the first time around and it also features a new game + mode, where you get to keep all your acquired items, but not upgrades and heart containers, and enemies do double damage.


[b]Presentation & Soundtrack[/b]:

The game looks gorgeous in all of its retro glory and is populated with many lovable side characters, witty dialogue and some great 4th wall breaking moments (many of them courtesy of the reoccurring character, the self-proclaimed filler boss Squid Baron), amazing 16 -bit animations and it's the small details that really made me take notice. Shantae, as mentioned previously, is a seductive belly dancer, and sometimes she might start to sway her hips side to side to Jake Kaufman's expertly produced soundtrack. Even when you are crawling on the ground or carrying Rottytops, Shantae's green zombie friend, who just so happens to have a thing for genie brains, Shantae is shaking her behind or stepping to the beat.

The music is upbeat and absolutely brilliant and accompanies each stage perfectly. Jake Kaufman further enforces my strong need for great musical scores in video games because they can really make or break your gaming experience. With Shantae and The Pirates Curse, its top notch and I certainly don't blame her for dancing. 

[b]Verdict[/b]:

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse offers superb animation quality, a downright awesome soundtrack and addicting gameplay that will certainly make you want to come back for more. It might not the best Metroidvania style game out there, but it is one of the most memorable and fun retro style games that i've ever experienced. Her hips don't lie and neither do I, so get this game, you will not regret it.

[b]9/10[/b]

20040360.review:
In a nutshell: I really enjoyed this game.

"Shantae and the Pirate's Curse" made me feel like I was back playing my old SNES. For a game made in 2014, it does an excellent job of capturing that classic old platformer feel and gameplay. But the appeal of this game doesn't end with the nostalgia factor. There's some really good humor in this game which makes for a really enjoyable play experience and the puzzles can get a bit tricky; not so much that they become a nuisance, but just enough to make you clever when you figure them out.

The characters were great and had a surprising amount of depth for a game that shows so much cleavage (pun not intended). There's a lot of character development in this game and, especially by the end, I found myself caring more then I would have expected about what happened to them and their relationships with one another. For me, this was one of the game's most endearing qualities.

On the negative side, this game does have it's imperfections, too. I mentioned earlier how this was a very loyal SNES-era style platformer and it is, in both the good ways and the bad. Playing Shantae and the Pirate's Curse reminded me why I would sometimes get so frustrated as a kid that I'd throw my controller at the wall. Things like timed jumps and frustratingly narrow gaps between spike filled walls, when not used properly, can easily become a nuisance which detracts from the enjoyability of a game. Shantae and the Pirate's Curse unfortunately succumbs to this pitfall. Long sequences that relied upon me timing numerous jumps perfectly - under threat of being sent back to the beginning over and over and over until I got it right- were aggrivating and the game would've been much better if they had been made so that you only took damage when you made a mistake, instead of being sent back to the beginning. The final journey to the big-boss was the most notorious culprit here, but there were other areas that suffered from the same problem. Forcing a player to replay long sequences over and over and over is annoyingly repetative and makes for a poor impression of the game as a whole.

Also, while I was able to get my Logitech Precision gamepad to work with this game, it required me to do some serious tweaking with some 3rd party software to get it to work and I was a little disappointed that Shantae and the Pirates Curse didn't include native support for it. "Shantae and the Pirate's Curse" is the kind of game that is really meant to be played with a controller (I briefly tried to play it via keyboard and I found it really awkward and hard on the fingers), so it's a shame there wasn't more effort put in to insuring that the game was more compatible with controllers.

But I won't let these minor frustrations ruin what was overall a really fun game! This game was well worth the money I paid for it and I will be eagerly awaiting it's sequel!

19983038.review:
After having played Shantae: Risky's Revenge, I had already fallen in love with this series, and Shantae was already one of my 2 favorite video game characters of all time! For a single game to be able to do that speaks volumes about its quality. Now let's take this already flawless platformer and make it even better. What do you get?  You get Shantae and the Pirate's Curse.

HOLY COW!!! This game is incredible! It somehow managed to take everything the previous games did right and perfect it. The game mechanics, from hair whipping to hat parachuting to simple running and walking animations, are very fluid and wildly entertaining to witness. The pace of the game is never too slow because you're always getting new items, which each give the game a new level of depth. The various levels you explore are vibrant and colorful, or dark and forboding if it's a dangerous level, but the tone matches each stage perfectly and helps to draw you into the world. All the characters are incredibly loveable and fun, and the character models themselves are stunningly beautiful from an artistic perspective! The music is also ridiculously catchy!

I have tried, but I honestly CANNOT find a single problem with this game. The developers at WayForward have poured their hearts and souls into this game...and it really shows! As I have said previously on my review of Shantae: Risky's Revenge, this is a series that should absolutely be played. I can personally guarentee that you will not be disappointed if you buy this game, even at full price! Thanks WayForward Games for my favorite Half-Genie!

Don't worry about my playtime, I fully completed the game on 3DS originally, and liked this game so much I had to buy it a second time.  

This is easily one of the best Shantae games yet: great controls, cute character art and vibrant world design, and plenty of collectibles to keep you playing for a while.  

The only possibly negative thing I would mention is something potentially a little divisive.  If Risky's Revenge turned you off from Shantae with it's confusing world design that had you jumping between the foreground and the background to navigate the world, you'll be pleased to know that's gone for a more traditional, and much easier to navigate, single plane.  However, if you liked it, you might be disappointed at the simplification.  

Shantae doesn't have her trademark transformations here, but they more than make up for them with some really fun gadgets that, among other things, let her rocket jump through the air, charge through obstacles, and shoot at faraway switches.  

+Pros

+ Catchy background music!
+ Fun platforming!
+ Gadgets mix the gameplay up!

-Cons

This is a solidly "pretty good" metroidvania platformer. The platforming and combat are both good, the bosses are well-designed, and the difficulty ramps up very nicely. The beginning is very easy but by the end there's some fiendishly difficult platforming sections.

19525867.review:
シャンティシリーズの第3作目。

ストーリーは前作のRisky's Revenge終了後のお話であり、そこでの登場キャラは全員続投しているためできるのなら前作をプレイしてからのほうが楽しめるだろう。
もちろんストーリ的にはそれぞれ独立したお話なので、いきなり今作からプレイしても特に問題はない。
前作のことがよくわからなければ、とりあえずシャンティ（主人公）がリスキーブーツ（紫肌の人）と敵対しこれを退けたが、その影響で魔法の力を失った、ということだけわかっていればOK。
よって前作は使えた魔法や変身は今作では使えない。
そのかわりにストーリーが進むと入手できる特殊なアイテムによりシャンティの行動や攻撃方法が増えていくのが特徴。

プレイ感覚としては、前作に比べて操作性が格段に向上している。
特にジャンプ周りの動きはかなりよくなっており、ピョンピョンと軽快な動作で跳び回れる。
またストーリが進むと出来るようになる特殊動作も、前作はベリーダンスを踊って変身する必要があったが今作はボタン一つで即時に実行可能。
結果的にアクションゲームとして非常にスピーディなプレイが可能となっている。

難易度は難しすぎず、易しすぎずのちょうどいい塩梅に感じた。
マップデザイン的には敵との戦闘よりもむしろ、トゲトゲやら落とし穴が強敵。
とはいえ穴に落ちたりトゲに刺さったりしても即死ではなく、ライフが減ったうえで部屋の入口に戻されるだけなのでそこまでストレスではない。
またボス戦は、倒すのに特定の手順を踏まなければならないタイプで倒し方がわかるまではちょこっとだけ苦戦するかもしれない。
ただ前作同様、今回も回復アイテムを大量に持ち込んでのゴリ押しが可能なため、倒せなくて困るってことはまずないだろう。
ゲーム作成者もそれはわかっているのか、全ボスにノーダメージ撃破実績が存在する。
余裕があれば狙ってみよう。

欠点としては、次にどこに行くのかがわかりにくいことが挙げられる。
新しいマップのダンジョンに入るためには、過去のマップのアイテムを回収しに戻ったり、町でイベントを起こす必要があるのだが、これがちょっとわかりづらい。
この点だけは改善してほしかった。
それとゲームプレイには直接関係ないが、現時点で日本語がないことが少し残念。
一応すべてのセリフを飛ばしてもクリアは可能だが、ストーリーやキャラの掛け合いもこのゲームの大きな魅力の一つなので、それらを飛ばすのはもったいない。
幸い全セリフを訳してくださるサイトが存在するので、そこを見ながらやるといいかもしれない。

総評としては、非常に出来の良い2Dアクションゲームだと思います。
ゲームの出来はもちろんの事、より日本人好みになった立絵や、素晴らしい音楽など細かい所まで満足なゲームでした。
かなり強くオススメできる一本です。

19418366.review:
*ahem* Dear Wayforward,
We need more Shantae....that is all....


                 Sincerely,

A very satisfied action/platformer gamer who thoroughly enjoyed the GBC original release, this, and Risky's Revenge: Director's Cut.

Now that that's outta the way, on to the review.

On the surface, it's just an average everyday platforming puzzle solving game, however, the style and story are very well done and the variety of available sub-weapons and special moves adds to the fun.  I wish we'd seen the return of the belly-dancing transformations, but given this is a direct sequel to Risky's Revenge, I can see why they opted to leave the half-genie stuff out, seeing as she lost all her powers in Risky's Revenge.

Graphics: 4.5 - The colors are vibrant and the backgrounds vary from island to island.  Still, it's a bit dated, but for this type of game, it's not a bad thing at all.  This game is set to stand the test of time as it just looks good and easy on the eyes.  Be prepared for MORE BUTT WIGGLES!

Sound: 4.5 - the voice-over work was interesting, but I wish they'd run with it a bit more.  It would have been a bit more engrossing having at least the dialogs between main characters/villains with voice-overs.  Still, Shantae's voice is cute and lovable.  The music does the job well setting up the scenarios and scenes everywhere.  

Controls: 5 - I'm using a 360 controller that's working flawlessly while I play.  The occasional ducking is a problem, but that's the CONTROLLER, not the game itself.  I fault Microsoft for that one because the d-pad, while great, is sometimes too sensitive and I find myself ducking and crawling when I meant to run forward.

Replay: 4.5 - Even if this game is short, I still find myself always going back to platformers and playing them again.  This is why Super Mario Bros. series has always stood the test of time.  I always find myself going back and playing those games and I'm sure to find myself coming back to Shantae and playing it over again.  Still, I wish there were a few extra things to do during a 2nd playthrough.  Even Risky's Revenge: Director's Cut had the alternate costume playthrough, but still, I will most likely find myself coming back to play this again even after I've completed it 100%.

For followers of Shantae, definitely worth it.  Those new to the series may find it a little lacking, but the gameplay is solid and flawless in controls.  Anyone looking for a quick platforming fix will find plenty to like in this and the earlier entries of the series.  Steam and the world needs more platformers as solid as Shantae is and hope that there's future entries in this series.

19179531.review:
Great game and fine port for pc from 3DS and arguably the best shantae game.
[h1]The Good Stuff[/h1]
+fanservice. boobs bounce a lot and female characters are all thicc, [spoiler]there's a bikini scene with two 1 shot characters[/spoiler]
+good level design but some sections are flawed, there's about 2 sections forcing you to restart from the last save point or fall into a bottomless pit to reset once you ruin something.
+Jake Kaufman. ever played shovel knight? if you have played it then you know what you're getting into with the soundtrack.
+good writing, not an award winning narrative but the game features great characters and a great  sense of humor
+gameplay makes up for the occationally flawed designs and contraptions, lots of moves, a fun metroidvania esque pace, its shovel knight quality but depending on your tastes you may or may not want to replay the game the moment you finish it, i personally did because i was hooked, and its a feeling i don't get as often from games anymore, and i loved it for that alone.
[h1]Issues some people may have[/h1]
-some may argue a few of the plot points were frustrating or straight up dumb but im fine with the narrative it follows.
-no 3rd party controller support for windows so its either an xbox controller or keyboard.
-not quite a metroidvania game, exploration doesn't feel as free as a metroidvania game should feel like due to how traveling is formated, its more like a mix between a modern mario level select and a 3D zelda overworld.
-backgrounds are no where near as good as they are on 3DS, they look stretched and are somewhat distracting
-not the most appropiate game to get your kids thanks to the scantily clad women.
[h1]RECOMMENDATION[/h1]
Its a solid platformer with decent lenght and value, good introduction to the metroidvania genre due to the simplified exploration and minimized backtracking but you might be dissapointed if you are looking for a huge map to get lost in, shigeru miyamoto fans as well as perverts are bound to adore this. (the humor is still one of the best parts of the game)

19052001.review: Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a massive improvement over the previous games in the series, giving abilities to the player that activate instantly upon a button press and favoring faster progression.  Gameplay-wise, it's what teh previous game SHOULD have been.  The game-pad controls make it so much easier to get into than Risky's Revenge, which I played with Keyboard (So that might be why), and the story is light-hearted and comical but knows just when to get serious.  The tone is always changing and always perfect for every moment in the game, and the Metroidvania aspect isn't as frustrating, except for a few specific instances, as previous titles in the series.  All in all, if you are trying to get the real ending (Multiple endings depending on if you got all the dark-magic or not) than you'll probably end up with a game lasting a few hours, mine was eight but I overpreppared for the final boss (I was worried that I sucked at the game more than I did) and missed a single dark magic so I had to fight him twice to get the right ending.  So a few hours, not that long, maybe not worth the full price, but ONLY if you want your money to exclusively buy very long games.  It's short, despite being hte longest game in teh series thus far, but you have to ask yourself, "A long but mediocre game, or a short but awesome one?"  Extra Credits on Youtube said it perfectly, "Awesome Per Second."

19022014.review: Shantae and the Pirate’s Curse is the third and most refined entry of the series thus far, forming what is now called the “sprite trilogy”. In this installment, Shantae teams up with longtime series antagonist Risky Boots on a quest to tame an ancient curse that threatens all of Sequin Land. Bereft of her genie magic, Shantae must instead make use of powerful pirate items: Risky’s pistol, hat, boots, scimitar and cannon, to traverse the world. The overworld and warp points of the earlier games are replaced with a free-roaming stage select, where Risky’s ship takes you to each of the levels, and she can be talked to at almost any time to leave your current island and travel elsewhere, up to the very end of the game. Easily twice the length of Risky’s Revenge, Pirate’s Curse retains most of the advances made in that game and also brings back a number of elements not seen since the original GBC game, most notably, the bathhouse in Scuttle Town that lets your recover health for free. Also, reloading a save will refill Shantae’s health. Pike balls are once again consumables as in the original, and the storm puffs and fireballs are gone, but Risky’s Pistol provides unlimited ranged attacks and can be upgraded, like Shantae’s hair, for more damage. Shantae can use the hat to glide, the scimitar to pogo-jump enemies a la Shovel Knight, the boots to do a Super Metroid-style boost run, and the cannon to do up to three additional jumps, altogether making Shantae her most maneuverable self yet. The same great sprites seen in Risky’s Revenge are augmented with new character art, new music, and a variety of new environments and enemies that revisit those seen in Shantae 1. Other new editions include consumable items that boost Shantae’s attack damage, food items that drop off enemies and restore various amounts of health, and “pirate flares” that allow you to return to Risky at any time, so long as you are outdoors. Overall, Pirate’s Curse is considerably more challenging then Risky’s Revenge but not to the point of frustration- falling into a death pit or touching the spikes merely removes a single hit point and returns you to the entrance of the current room, and you can have a total of forty, and carry enough health items to render an actual game over a near-impossibility- thanks to the addition of auto-potions that trigger automatically upon losing all your health. It is not however, anywhere near as cheap as the first game, and for that I am thankful. If you liked the previous Shantae titles, Metrodivanias or platformers of any kind, Shantae and the Pirate’s Curse is a treat for your eyes, ears and fingers that should not be missed.

18768542.review:
How many times have you encountered a threequel that's better than both the original and the sequel combined? Well, you've already encountered one of them -- I'm reviewing it right now and you're reading it. Again, I don't think words can possibly describe WHY this game is amazing, so I'll just write a few of the little things I love about this game in no particular order.

1. Charging through every area in Risky's boots (this also functions as an anti-frustration feature if you want to buy something but you haven't a single gem to your name, as it's a very quick and easy way to get money and items)

2. RISKY REDEMPTION ARC. I repeat, RISKY. REDEMPTION. ARC!

3. The art (I especially love the new Rottytops)

4. Rottytops in general (and all the other characters -- everyone is more likeable in this game)

5. Pretty much all of Shantae's interactions with Risky from Saliva Island onwards are ADORABLE (especially arriving at each island, where there's always that moment Shantae forgets Risky used to be her nemesis)

6. If you don't get all the cacklebats before the final boss, you'll feel more horrible for it than when you unlocked the "heart of stone" and "play dead" achievements in Risky's Revenge. That's right, it has two endings. I can't imagine a better ending than the "true ending," though. Never in my life have I wanted to hug a pirate so much in either ending.

7. MELT! THEM!! DOWN!!!

8. "Men are idiots. At least I still have Wrench." -- Sky (this is also her card quote, by the way)

9. Shantae trying to be a pirate (I just really wish Risky was there to hear "moist the main snail")

10. THE MUSIC. SALIVA ISLAND. SPIDERWEB ISLAND. Just... ALL OF THE MUSIC.

18401466.review:
Sinceramente, uno de los mejores plataformas que he jugado. Súper divertido de principio a fin.

Bastante mejor que el anterior, no solo por la variedad de los escenarios, o más bien las mazmorras, que en el anterior todas se parecían, sino por los objetos que vas recogiendo a medida que avanzas en la historia. Como unas botas para hacer un ataque de carga y así superar ciertas zonas inestables o una pistola que te permite accionar dispositivos desde lejos.

No hay transformaciones como en su predecesor, ya que en esta parte Shantae no posee magia. Sin embargo, en mi opinión, no es algo que importe, pues los objetos que te van dando son muy divertidos y cómodos de usar.

El control es una delicia, responde perfectamente y eso se agradece muchísimo, la sensación que tienes al mover a Shantae es brutal, y aunque parezca una tontería, no lo es.

La banda sonora también es muy buena, acompaña perfectamente al ambiente y no cansa, y hay algunos temas que telita.

La única pega que le veo es que es muy corto, unas 6 horas me ha llevado completarlo al 100%, aunque aún me quedan 2 logros, pero son de speedruns, y odio los speedruns xD. Pero al que le guste pues más horas le dará. Al completar el juego desbloqueas el modo pirata que hace que empieces el juego con todos los objetos, para así facilitar el speedrun.

En definitiva, uno de los mejores plataformas que se han hecho, en mi opinión. Si eres fan del género, es compra obligada.

Best Shantae game of the series at time of this posting, it feels a bit simplified in the exploration department, but what it trades for is worth it. Far more sensable level design and better flow with the new 'powers' while making the story feel more complete though just as silly. The game is funny, with a lot of funny dialogue and things to do.

Some levels have some crazy tricks to sort out but nothing too hard if you've played any platformer game I'd wager. 

The other Shantae games suffered a bit from difficulty spikes or overcomplication of the powers & Navigation which this game overcomes and creates a really fun game to go through. 
There's some reused assets from previous games but it comes buffed up and better than before. 

Got 100% in the game, really enjoyed my time through it and I see myself doing it all again.

17955718.review:
I find it difficult to rate this game.  Eventually I decided on a positive rating since I am glad I played it.  Besides, I know how this works.  If you disagree with the majority, your review will be downvoted into oblivion and never be seen, even if you have good reasons for your negative rating.

While I have nothing but praise for [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/277890/]Shantae: Risky's Revenge[/url], Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a mostly good game, marred by occasional bad level design and severe balance problems.

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse has fun abilities, great artwork and music, good humor, and sex appeal, just like the previous games in the series.  It is longer than Shantae: Risky's Revenge.

The only technical complaint I have is that it would have been nice to have the window scalable in windowed mode.  The developers have my thanks for adding key remapping.

As for general complaints about the level design and difficulty, there are many cheap hits.  Zombies often spring from the earth directly under you.  Ghosts often materialize on top of you.  These are an almost constant problem on Spiderweb Island.  The problem with Ghosts also happens on various other levels that include them.  When Scuttle Town becomes corrupted by dark magic, the Pumpkin Fields becomes black, except for the sky, making it almost impossible to see enemies or their projectiles, since they blend in perfectly with background elements like foliage.

There are several unique, and bad (uniquely bad), level designs.

On Spiderweb Island there is an area where you have to carry another character.  This prevents you from attacking or ducking, and causes you to die in one hit.  Some timing in this area is unreasonably tight.  The worst offender is the room where you are in tunnels with too little headroom to jump until you reach an area near the end with a platform overhead, and a kissing robot at the other end that is running toward you.  There is only a few pixels of space between you and the robot when you successfully make the jump, which will likely take many, many attempts.  This area is agonizingly long, like most of the problem levels.  When I play a Shantae game, I want to play a Metroidvania, [i]not a racing game[/i].

On Tan Line Island there is an area where you have to stealthily escape a palace.  This prevents you from attacking or using any special abilities, and causes you to restart the entire area if you are spotted once.  You are expected to make use of new mechanics, like blending into the shadows, without any explanation, and given the severity of the punishment for any mistake, experimentation is extremely unpleasant.  This area is agonizingly long, again, like most of the problem levels.  While I [i]like[/i] stealth games (a lot, I am very fond of [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/211600/]Thief[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/205100/]Dishonored[/url], and [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/214560/]Mark of the Ninja[/url]), this is like playing a [i]bad[/i] stealth game.  The player has almost no means avoiding enemies other than moving out of their sight.  No distractions, no clever movement options, no disguises…  Making a mistake sets you back far too much.  When I play a Shantae game, I want to play a Metroidvania, [i]not a stealth game[/i].

By far the worst area in the game is the Pirate Master's Palace.  The area is lifeless except for a few Bats and Save Guy.  It is mostly full of instant-kill spikes.  Like the other bad areas, it looks like it was lifted from other games.  In this case, [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/70300/]VVVVVV[/url] and [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flappy_Bird]Flappy Bird[/url].  Like other bad areas, it is agonizingly long.  I died around 30 times in the first room before finding a way to bypass the first 3 rooms on Youtube.  After that, I was able to complete this area, but the process left me so infuriated and exhausted that I am unlikely to ever play through the game again.  This area officially “ruined the game for me”.  When I play a Shantae game, I want to play a Metroidvania, [i]not Super Meat Boy or Flappy Bird[/i].

The final boss is almost as badly balanced as the level he lives in.  Until I encountered him, I had avoided sacrificing any Heart Squid children to make Heart Holders.  I wanted to finish the game that way.  Unfortunately, each hit he lands is enough to instantly kill Shantae without any Heart Holder upgrades, and attacks like his bouncing cannon balls and flying pistols seem to be impossible to avoid even with a Bubble Shield.  9 Auto-Potions was not enough to see me through the battle.  Despite being squeamish about it, and it costing me the achievement, I melted all the Heart Squid children I found into Heart Holders so I could finish the game and write this review.

WayForward, if you are reading this, and I hope you are, please keep releasing more of this series, but make future releases fun, not frustrating.

17842416.review:
《Shantae and the Pirate's Curse》是一款2D平台動作冒險遊戲，強調逐步探索進而解鎖能力的Metroidvania風格玩法（名稱取自銀河戰士和惡魔城的特色玩法）和個性鮮明逗趣可愛的人物設定，馬上就成為當年任天堂3DS平台眾所矚目的話題強作之一，筆者發現近期以復古風格為主題的動作冒險遊戲再次被市場所重視，這也證明了在次世代畫質大比拚的遊戲業界中，還是有部分玩家跟筆者一樣，寧願去選擇2D復古風的作品遊玩。遊戲中總共支援六大島嶼供玩家進行探索，遊戲時數初見一周目大概會花上七到十小時，我們會在遊戲中扮演將紫色秀髮當作武器使用的半精靈女英雄桑塔，與大反派女海盜蕾斯基破天荒攜手合作，保衛自己的家鄉並且阻止海盜王的邪惡詛咒禍害人間。


為什麼我會一口咬定《Shantae and the Pirate's Curse》是款表現出色的遊戲呢？答案是有始有終的故事劇情、印象深刻的人物設定、拿捏得宜的遊戲難度。先讓我們從故事劇情說起，遊戲中的故事劇情相當簡單易懂，英雄拯救世界一直都是廣為玩家接受的老梗劇情，故事主角桑塔的任務就是拯救世界，沒有其他撲朔迷離讓人看得霧煞煞的深奧劇情，也不會最後留下讓人腦洞大開的開放式結局讓玩家腦補。再來談談人物設定方面，就算是從沒接觸過系列作的玩家應該也會被人物立繪所吸引吧？一身小麥膚色的桑塔除了是名半精靈英雄之外，更是一名舞技熟練的舞孃，女海盜蕾斯基也是焦點人物之一，玲瓏有緻的身材加上大姊頭個性馬上獲得廣大M男關注，只能說兩位女主角的形象確實成為不少玩家購買本作的主因。


接下來談到遊戲難度，《Shantae and the Pirate's Curse》是一款難度中等的遊戲，只要玩家操縱桑塔進行遊戲，隨著故事的進展就能明顯感受到桑塔不斷提升自己的戰鬥能力，同時玩家更能取得女海盜蕾斯基的武器裝備，利用它們破解謎團並突破難關。每一座島嶼都會有強大的關卡頭目鎮守，如同多數的平台動作冒險遊戲，關卡頭目往往會有固定的行為模式，只要抓準時機閃躲就能無傷擊敗頭目，玩家也能花費打怪得到的寶石貨幣購買升級道具，讓桑塔的傷害與速度提高，總而言之本作難度不高，非常適合全年齡對象遊玩。

17806390.review: Shantae and the Pirate's Curse... reviewed! http://nintendodemandreviews.blogspot.com/2015/05/shantae-and-pirates-curse-reviewed.html

17803380.review:
The story:
A Long Time Ago, before the first Shantae, someone called Pirate Master died and left a curse for Risky Boots, after Risky's defeat in Risky's Revenge, Shantae's Light Genie Magic became Dark Magic, and the Tinkerbats became Cacklebats. On a side story, Ammo Baron has bought Scuttle Town from the Mayor, who bought chocolate... Again. Now, Shantae has to team up with Risky Boots to defeat the Pirate Master, collect the Dark Magic from the Cacklebats and rescue Scuttle Town from Ammo Baron.

Pros:
- Shantae's adventure is now bigger, better and harder
- Awesome OST
- The characters are well developed
- Lots of collectibles
- Two different endings: The Good One, and the Bad One. I prefer to call them as Best Ending and Worst Ending respectively as there is almost nothing bad in the 2nd ending
- There's one Nostalgia stage with music from Shantae from the Game Boy Color
- Each boss has a different subtitle
- 4 different In-Game Wallpapers

Cons:
- That Last Dungeon is harder than anything else
- Dagron is harder than the Last Boss

[h1] FINAL SCORE: 10/10 [/h1]
Long Story Short:
Shantae's adventure is bigger, better and much more interesting but you still need to play the other games to understand most of it. So buy this game and buy Risky's Revenge

17785447.review:
Superb game. Great gameplay, consisting of platforming, combat, and speedrunning, all coming together to create an incredibly fun experience. The story is compelling, being not too heavy, nor too light, while throwing in comedic moments and themes along with the more serious aspects. Voice work is minimal, but this works to the game's advantage, and what little there is is quite good. Sound quality itself is top-notch, and nothing more needs to be said about the soundtrack than to go download it on Bandcamp right now (it's free!). Art and animation are high quality, and I think a dramatic improvement over previous installments of the series. Replayability is high, and first-time players will find themselves with plenty to do even after completing the game, such as acheivements, wallpapers, and speedruns. Incidentally, this is the first Steam game in which I completed all acheivements.

Overall, 9.5/10 game, highly recommend.

17101882.review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a 2D metroidvania platformer adventure. You play as Shantae, the half genie guardian of Scuttle Town. Recently you have lost your magical powers, but you don't let that stop you from saving the town once trouble comes through. Most of the trouble is caused by evil magic being sent out by the imprisoned spirit of the Master Pirate. It's your job to team up with your former rival Risky Boots in order to stop his minions, collect the magic, and prevent his spirit's escape. 

The gameplay is fairly simple. You can run around, jump, duck, crawl, and whip your hair to attack. Along the way you will receive new items and upgrades to give yourself more abilities and more power. You use these abilities to access new areas in order to find secrets and progress. There are a few light puzzles and fetch quests sprinkled in, but the main play will consist of traversing overworlds and conquering dungeons. You can also increase your health and carry items to heal you on the go or to give you some other battle assistance. You'll need to skilled in combat, platforming, and adventuring to complete this game.

The music is overall pretty great, being polished and interesting to listen to. The art is a mixture of two styles. The playable game consists of colorful pixel art that is well animates, while the dialogue bits have hand drawn cartoonish representations of the characters. The sound effects are also an interesting mix of higher quality voice and sound sample along with retro style video gamey effects. The controls are tight and understandable. Plus, the dialogue is cute and can actually be funny at time. It's an interesting mixture.

For those who played Shantae: Risky's Revenge before this as I did, you'll be glad to know that nearly everything has been improved upon in this game. You get lots of new abilities rather than just recollecting the same ones from the previous game. The story is even more interesting with the same quality of dialogue. The hand drawn art is different, but it seems to have a bit more detail. This game has more length, with more places to explore, things to do, things to find, people to talk to, and just generally more everything, which means even more quality playtime. The difficulty is also higher for those looking for a greater challenge, which is welcome since this is a sequel, but not too hard for newcomers that would like to try it as well. The map system has been improved to read more like a standard metroidvania style map and show you where you have and have not been. If you liked exploring, platforming challenges, puzzle challenges, combat challenges, and just the overall gameplay of the previous game, you'll love this one even more.

There are a few issues with the game though. One that may have just been for me was that sometimes there was a flickering glitchy effect on some backgrounds. This usually only happened in the company logo right away and on the world selection screen, but it also did happen consistently in one temple where I kind of needed to know where the walls and floors were. It was only for that one room in the one temple, but it kept happening after a few reloads so it may be a real problem for others as well. Also, I didn't think the cartoonish characters hand drawn in dialogue scenes meshed well with the pixel style of the game. Mayb it's just me, but I would rather just keeping it all one way. That's minor. The difficulty could be a problem. It's harder than the previous game, which is good for people who played that first and it's not TOO hard for those who want to jump right in, but to some casual gamers it could be a bit too tough to get through. While I like that the map system has been reworked and the sailing aspect works will with giving Risky more purpose, it's a shame that instead of one big interconnected world it's now multiple smaller worlds you have to select separately.

Overall, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is awesome. If you like metroidvania games, it's a great one. If you played the previous game (which I also reviewed on here) and liked it, this is definitely worth looking into. It's a fun, metroidvania adventure platformer with a pretty style. I like how fun, challenging, and yet forgiving the game is to make it a lot of fun to keep playing. Another one of the best games I've played on Steam. Is it worth the 20 dollar asking price? Well, personally I would say that, if you're really interested and liked the other Shantae games, then of course. Otherwise maybe wait for a sale. I got it for 15 and it was worth not being able to wait anymore. If nothing else, getting it at 10 bucks or less at some point is going to be a real steal, especially for all the content here. Shantae and the Pirate's Curse gets a 9 out of 10 for being a great blend of genres, gameplay, personality, and style. Also... I know I'm a pervert but... I mean, come on, Shantae is a babe ;)

16890970.review:
Wow.

If you're played Risky's Revenge or read my review of the previous Shantae game, it's a pretty rough entry into the platforming genre. Pirate's Curse is, in turn, a vast improvement.

Though it retains the same sprites that were used on the DSi, the resolution is much sharper, with crisp, attractive backgrounds and new animations thrown in. This also makes the HD graphics used for conversations and menus a lot less jarring, but they still look a bit odd at first. Though enemy sprites are reused from Risky's Revenge, it also adds a lot more of theIt also has a lot more enemies, and new huge, screen-filling bosses help make hitting the end of a level a lot more exciting than before.

Shantae feels faster, jumps farther, giving a better feel to the controls, and her speed and leaping ability grow dramatically as you go through the game. Unlike the "lock and key" transformations of Risky's Revenge, which often don't see much use outside of opening up a new zone, you'll find yourself using most of the equipment which replaces the transformations in regular gameplay. The extra movement options also make traversing zones a lot easier. This time, the zones are connected through a central hub, and you readily can get items that return you to the hub. The exploration is much improved, though it still struggles a bit (being able to warp directly to dungeons, for example, would have saved a lot of tiresome trekking). The levels are now quite varied, often with different gimmicks other than just graphical stylings.

It's also a [i]lot[/i] funnier, and... might I say fairly fetishy by comparison, expecially during the early parts of the game. If that kind of thing bugs you, it will bug you. While it's not [i]quite[/i] Totally Spies, some pretty odd fetishes feel like they're checked. I just find it amusing, but others might find the humiliating nature of some of the situations more problematic. Still, the dialogue is far more clever than earlier iterations, and generally got me to at least crack a smile at some of the back-and-forths.

Even those "stop 'n go" enemies I hated from the previous game are improved. For example, Riskys' Revenge had mermaid enemies that would try to bore you to death through periods of invulnerability, but now their windows of invulnerability are now far briefer. In addition, often Shantae can dispatch enemies much faster... or, later in the game, just heedlessly charge through them or float over them. Magic has been replaced with limited-use items, though in some areas they drop often enough you may as well use them all the time. Overall, it's a clunky system compared to refreshing magic, but it's not a real black mark.

Ultimately, Pirate's Curse is a lot of fun. Where Risky's Revenge relied mostly on charm and nostalgia for appeal, Pirate's Curse has a lot more substance. It often has different sequences where it offers variations on the core gameplay to keep things from being too monotonous, and the new equipment keeps shifting how you play the game. Thumbs down on a final level that suddenly kicks up the difficulty drastically and frustratingly, but at least is capped by a very satisfying end boss.  Though it's not a breakthrough or a massive innovation in the genre, it's a very solid platformer that feels and plays great, and gives me a lot of hope for the upcoming HD sequel.

16777579.review:
This is what I call an improvement!

If you check my profile, you can see that I played and reviewed an earlier installment of the series: Risky's Revenge. While it was lacking in some aspects it was cool enough that after the convincing gameplays I decided to jump back to the series. This is definitely more fun and polished game and I can easily say it is worth your interest with only few hiccups along the way. If the game is solid, then I'm more than happy to nitpick some issues for further ironing out for the next Wayfoward's game. Criticism makes excellence!

Game is notably faster than the Risky's Revenge. The previous game was pretty sluggish at times, but the improved controls, Shantae's speed and jumps in pair with good level design, help dictate a reasonable pace that makes you flow through the game with no noticeable frustrating moments. Graphics are in my favorite 16/32-bit Mega Man X4-rish style, that didn't really change after Revenge (with recycled sprites), but it still looks pretty nice, especially with the new locations. Bosses are definite plus. While not very challenging, they provide fun encounters. There are a lot of new faces as regular enemies which are good to see. Platforming? No complains there.

Music deserves an separate paragraph. Jake Kaufman did probably his best score yet. In my opinion it's far better than Shovel Knight's and provides tons of catchy memorable tunes that really "sells" the game. I would say that without this soundtrack, many locations wouldn't be as fun and atmospheric as they are now, since many of them are pretty generic. Mud Bog Island with Village of Lost Souls hidden within it is an great example of climatic location boosted by an amazing music. This stuff rocks.

The story. Characters are likeable and unique, scenes are full of humor and plot overall isn't particularly offensive, but...

Logic? Out of commission. Setups? Wasted potential. Lore? Barely touched.

It looks like the devs had a plenty ideas for funny situations and hijinks between characters. There are lots of mini character arcs that bring this thing together, but logic behind why scene A resulted in events in scene B is completely bizarre. It fits the convention and style, but for me it is something of a missed opportunity. Keep in mind that this is a nitpick and Shantae doesn't need a great story to be an awesome game, but I would say that this is an aspect for further improvement.

Upgrades. They are all powerful and really fun to use... unless we are talking about the Sword upgrade that is only useful for unlocking vertical shafts and nothing more. It gives no advanced mobility and is pretty weak against enemies. No sense in using instead of standard hair whip. Pistol and additional melee attacks also become obsolete really fast, but other upgrades are extremely fun to use and tinker with.

As for a completely minor sidenote, which doesn't hurt the game that much, but I would like to point it out... There is also a strange dissonance in level progression vs. classic Metroidvania mechanics. Shantae controls would really shine in level-to-level progression system (intro level shows this), but this series was very exploration heavy from the start. Game tries to bring the best of both worlds, but levels are not-seamlessly connected and they are overall pretty small, so there isn't as much exploration as in standard Metroidvania and there are not enough set-pieces as for classic platformer. You can really feel it, as the game has less adventurish feel and yet doesn't deliver as much level-specific excitement as Freedom Planet or Shovel Knight. Luckily, this is subjective and not very noticeable. It doesn't affect the enjoyment as much, probably thanks to the overall solid experience crafted by the devs.

The only proper negative that I can think of is the price. Content-wise, it offers a similar about of fun and features as afromentioned Shovel Knight and Freedom Planet, yet it's price tag is 5 dollars higher. 15 bucks is a perfect price for fun and enjoyment you will get from Pirate's Curse. It's solid platform game that is definitely worth your interest since it holds up a great quality on par with other genre representatives. If you are a platforming fan, then you are making yourself a disservice if you won’t put it on your wishlist!

16731925.review:
Well, I have a lot of good things to say about this one. For starters, I didn't play any other Shantae games other than this. But judging by the trailers for the other games, I can easily assume this is the best. This game came out last year on 3DS and Wii U, and just a few months ago was ported to the PC. Here's my review.

The game plays like your average platformer. You control Shantae, who uses her hair to whip enemies, although later she gets upgrades like a gun, etc. The controls feel very smooth and responsive. You travel through six locations where you have to accomplish certain things and then go to the dungeon of the world. This heavily reminds me of Zelda, especially considering there are chests, keys, items, puzzles, etc. There are also a lot of secret items throughout the game. You can get jellies, which you can turn into health, and there are also bats I think that give you dark magic (you'll find out the use as you play). Also, you can use money earned from defeating enemies to buy one-time items (spike balls, shields, potions, etc.) or permanent upgrades (faster whip, more powerful, etc.). One thing I don't like is that some items are hidden in places that you either don't see (so either you have to get to them by complete accident or by trial and error), or that look like you can get them but you really can't. For example, there is a section in the sand that has tiny platforms that break upon touching them. I got very frustrated trying to get it, only to give up and learning that you can get it, but only after getting an upgrade. If it was more obvious that I couldn't get it, then I wouldn't have to be frustrated.

Presentation-wise, this game has great graphics. They are in a 16-bit SNES style, although on top of that, there are full artworks of the characters in-dialogs. For some reason, WayForward decided to use a default font for the dialogs, which looks quite ugly and annoying if you ask me. The soundtrack? Don't even ask. It's f*cking amazing. The composer also made the soundtrack for Shovel Knight, Duck Tales Remastered, Contra 4, etc. There isn't full voice acting, only occasional words by certain characters are pronounced, ususally sound good, but can get annoying at times.

Well, this game isn't super long either. You can beat it in three hours easily. Do I recommend it? Definitely. It is a little expensive compared to other indies (20$), but I still think it's worth it. Buy it, you'll like it!

16659871.review:
[h1]This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.[/h1]

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a platformer game which was initially released on the Nintendo 3DS and WiiU. It's the third in the Shantea series. I haven't played any of the previous one so I was a little behind on the story here.  The game was released initially in 2014 and was ported to Steam in April of 2015. The 3DS release of this game was actually nominated for the best platformer and was also in the Top 10 games in the Nintendo 2014 survey of fans favorites 

You play as Shantae, who is a half-genie. You goal in the game is to save everyone from "The Pirate Master", with the help of her what appears to be long standing nemesis, named Risky Boots. 

Throughout the game you will find various different "pirate equipment" such as pistols and cannons, these items are all used at various points in order to progress through the story. You can also upgrade all of your equipment too to make them more effective. This game is said to be the biggest in the series in terms of how many locations are included for you to explore. We also see a familiar mini-map screen you will have seen in Metroidvania style games before. The actual gameplay is very Metroidvania too, lots of jumping puzzles, thought based puzzles, enemies, collecting jewels and gems to find and chests with equipment and keys in to find. 

The game uses a 2D graphics engine, which I can imagine looks pretty good on the 3DS, however it does look like a bit of an emulated game on the PC. The dialog scenes look nice, but the actual in game graphics are very pixelated, granted some people enjoy that style so that may right be up your street. 

I must warn you, this game is not easy at all. You will die, and die, and die plenty of times. It may even have you rage quitting at points that it is so frustrating, but you can't help but load it up again in order to move on. The difficulty curve is very up and down, sometimes you can be going through one level and think its actually quite easy, then all of a sudden you are failing countless times on a specific area in the zone. Being hard is not a bad thing at all; it's actually something I really look for in a game. I did have to revert to Youtube videos for hints on how to get past some levels though.

A full playthrough of Shantea and the Pirate's Curse took me almost six hours. Sadly I don't think there is much replay-ability to be had here; once you playthrough it the once - there is really no other reason to playthrough it again. 

This is actually a well put together port to the PC. The developers have gone to the effort of adding full controller support along with a graphically helpful control screen to go along with it. I would highly recommend you play this game with a controller aswell; playing on a keyboard would be a disaster. 

I would recommend Shantea and the Pirate's Curse; but not at full price. I think the six hours it took me to complete along with the zero amount of replay-ability means you should really be picking this up on sale. However I did enjoy playing it, it is in no way a bad game. I am looking forward to trying out the other games in this series now!

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

http://store.steampowered.com/app/345820

Your hair is your weapon in this cool action adventure

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7FwQvJx6M8s

Shantae is a hair-whipping belly dancing genie. When she loses her magic, Shantae must team up with her nemesis, the nefarious pirate Risky Boots in order to save Sequin Land from an evil curse. As a pirate, Shantae gains new weapons to advance her quest, slay monsters, battle epic bosses…and hopefully get her magic back in the bargain! But can she really trust her deadliest enemy?

The third Shantae game is the biggest yet! Beyond Sequin Land lie cursed islands and labyrinths each hiding a new piece of Pirate Gear - Flintlock Pistol, Pirate Hat, Scimitar, Risky's Boots, and even a Cannon. Upgrade Shantae's hair and weapons or unlock advanced Fighter's Moves. Locate maps, return lost Heart Squids, collect rare loot, and laugh out loud at the weird, wild, and wonderfully humorous cast of characters. Incredible high resolution artwork, unlockable Pirate-Mode, multiple endings, and an unforgettable soundtrack make this one game you won't want to miss! - Recommended!

15832038.review:
Shantae, the half-genie heroine of Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, is more than just an upstart in the Metroidvania genre – she's the new star. At a glance, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse may look like a game for kids, but it's actually very deep and expertly designed, appealing on a variety of levels from platforming and exploration, to music and visual style. I love the sense of humor, too – there are tons of outrageous gags that make both the good guys and the bad guys completely lovable. 

More so than its predecessor, Risky's Revenge, Pirate's Curse feels like a platformer, with more clearly-defined levels (islands that you sail to) and difficult platforming segments that require multiple attempts to complete. There's a general lack of warp points within the levels, which can make for a bit of frustration when you realize that you have to go through an entire area again to pick up something you missed. Also, the whole game feels a bit too small, and I wish there were more support items to use (like the pike balls) to add more depth to the gameplay.

Problems aside, Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is the most fun I've had with this genre since the classic 2D Castlevania games. It's funny, stylish, and all-around an outstanding game that I heartily recommend. 

(Rating: 8.5/10 “Excellent”)

Notes: I played Shantae and the Pirate's Curse with an Xbox 360 Controller for Windows. I recommend using a console controller like this for all platformer-type games, since it allows for greater precision control.

15819796.review:
A fun and easy to play metroidvania that doesn't overstay its welcome.  The big difference between this and Risky's Revenge gameplay-wise is that the various animal forms are exchanged for pieces of pirate equipment that hit all the cues of a metroidvania; you have your triple jump, speed dash, hover ability, et al.

Stage layout and dungeon design are simple enough, but the "overworld" aspects of each island is a little too similar outside of their general theme.  The game is collectible friendly in that each level keeps a visible tally of how many hidden items are each level and how many you have already tracked down.  There's enough stuff to find to incentivize revisiting areas but not too many that looking for secrets feels like a slog or unrewarding.  

The soundtrack is as nice and catchy as is most of Jake “virt” Kaufman's stuff.  The spritework is good and the game controls well.  Using the inventory/map is a little clunky, but not a big negative by any means.  Pirate's Curse is a relatively easy game, though it has a couple of areas that can be kind of a pain, like the stealth section and a final leg that's significantly harder platforming-wsie than the rest of the game, though it's not especially hard.

All in all, a nice little game that will take most people between 8-12 hours to finish but I can see it having a good bit of replaybility since once you beat the game you can start a new game with all of your pirate skills unlocked from the start, so you can triple jump, speed dash and so on right from the start.  Shit like that rules and means I'll probably play this again some time in the future.

One last thing, if the idea of cartoon boobs drives you crazy and makes you want to make a forums post about it, pass on this.  There are tons of boobs everywhere but if you have any background with original property WayForward games, this isn't a surprise in the least.  WayForward loves boobs.  If you love cartoon boobs and metroidvania's, this is the game for you.

WayForward put a lot of heart into making Pirate's Curse, and it shows.

[list]
    [*]The music is excellent, courtesy of composing veteran Jake Kaufman. You might already know his work from Shovel Knight, Mighty Switch Force, DuckTales: Remastered, and the other Shantae games.

Would recommend to any fan of action platformers.
