15614190.review:
I never thought this game would be on Steam, but I'm glad it is. And even though I have not played any of its predecessors prior to it, I can positively say that this was a great introduction to a rather underrated franchise.


Storywise, it's pretty much like: "A great evil is attempting to rule over the land and you must stop it." I won't spoil what the rest is, but there ARE multiple endings.

Presentation: The menus are a bit simplistic, but they get the job done.

Art & Animation: Holy hell, are they FRIGGIN' AWESOME! just by LOOKING at the game you can see how much effort they put into character animations, especially in characters like Rottytops. The problem is some of the background can be a bit misleading. For example when I reached the part of Saliva Island with the Heart Squid (They increase your max health) behind stone walls, I thought that there was a secret room somewhere, but then I found out that the architecture on the upper-right corner was just background.

Performance: The game doesn't take much to run. Always a plus in my books.

Music: It's awesome, too! You got the pumping tracks of Tan Line Island and Scuttle Town, the dark and dreary Mud Bog Island and Village of Lost Souls, the cheery upbeat tracks of Propeller Town, the Tense Build-ups of the Pirate Master's Palace, and more.

Gameplay: Control is fairly tight, and thanks to a new update, a negative review has just been made redundant! The currency they use are called "Gems", but judging by the image in your HUD, they're Rupees. You can use them to buy Healing Items, Temporary attack buff items, Leaf Shie- I mean, Pike Balls, Pirate Flares which transport you back to the docks of an isand (Can't be used inside buildings/labyrinths), and Ability Upgrades/Advanced Moves (Like Jumping while KO'd in midair to recover.)

The upgrades are rather basic: Increase Damage and Speed with your hair, And damage for the rest. But the abilities are what sell it for me. ALL of them are used throughout the game: The Scimitar can be used to destroy blocks you can't destroy with your Whip/Pistol, the Pistol can be used to deal with distant enemies and switches, the Hat can be used to cross large gaps, the Boots to just speed through the entire thing while destroying everything in your way, and the Cannon, which gives you a Quadruple Jump (Cannonballs included).

Difficulty: It's a challenging game, but the curve is a little bit off. For the beginning islands, the real challenge lies in knowing what the heck to do, but then you enter Mud Bog Island and the challenge ramps up due to the sheer amount of enemies you have to deal with. Then you reach the final level, which is pretty much an obstacle course set to test how good you are with the abilties. Can you reach great heights with the Cannon? Can you maneuvre around Spikes with the hat? Can you dash to the end with the Boots? If not, you will be using at least 3 potions just for the entire obstacle course.

Replay Value: Unless you're a completionist or if the game is so good that you just want to play it again, there's not much replay value.


Verdict:

Presentation | 6.0/10 (Menus and dialogue boxes look simple, but it doesn't count much towards overall score.)

Art & Animation | 9.8/10 (The pixel art animations look amazing, the game is bursting with colour, and the character portraits during conversations are a nice touch. But some of the background can be a little misleading.)

Performance | 10/10 (Always ran at 60 Fps throughout the entire adventure.)

Music | 10/10 (The score is just plain awesome, nothing else needs to be said.)

Gameplay | 9.0/10 (Control is tight, abilities are useful, but the Hat can be a little clunky sometimes.)

Difficulty | 9.6 (The game is fairly challenging, but the curve is a little off, in my opinion.)

Replay Value | 3.5 (Unless you're a completionist, I can't see a reason to replay the game again.)

Overall | 9.4/10 (Apart from a few minor faults, and the fact that there's not much left to do once you beat the game, it's still a great game that every Metroidvania lover will enjoy.)


Misc bits of advice: If you played the original Shantae before this, once you have the Boots, charge into the left corner of the first room of the first labyrinth. You won't be disapointed.

Edit: I raised my review score because a recent update now allows you to change the controls, and gave Music/SFX sliders.

英語のテキスト量が多いので
ストーリーを完全に理解するには英語力が必要。
だがアクションとグラフィックを楽しむだけならば、
英語が分からなくても特に問題ない。
ゲームで詰まっても、以下の事をすれば大体進める。
・新しいアクションを使って行ける所を探す。
・立ち絵のあるキャラと話す
・ランプに何か吸い込む。

回復アイテムを多く持ち運べるので難易度は簡単。
難易度の変更はないがアイテム縛りをすれば
かなり難しくなると思う。

攻略するごとに増えるアクションは
対空時間増加や下突きなど使いやすいものが多くなった。
ワープポイントはなくなったが、
ステージの最初に戻れるアイテムを店で買える。

使い回しは多いがドット絵は綺麗で滑らか。
予想以上に露出度の高い立ち絵が多かったのも良かった。

前作から改善されている部分が多く、非常に楽しめた。
2Dアクションゲームとして高いレベルで纏まっており、
定価で買って満足できるゲームだった。

15579501.review:
Third in the series, if this is an indicator of 1/2 Genie Hero I can't wait!

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a fun platformer made by WayForward. Game has metroidvania gameplay with an insanely good soundtrack and a fun story, Artstyle and sprites are amazing and the game is a blast to play throughout. Definitely a GOTY in my opinion.

15569579.review:
After finishing the game, I can honestly tell you that this is one of the best platformers I played in years. Compared to Risky's Revenge, this is like 100x better, so if you liked Risky's Revenge, this one is a must buy.

PRO's: 

- Perfect controls - never had a fail jump or miss-shot due to controls

- Fun and addictive game - the characters are fun, as-well as the story and you will hardly get bored while playing

- Graphics - a pixelated masterpiece. The characters and environments are rich in color and animation. Not one zone looks the same as another

- Music - what good is a game without some quality music? Each zone has it's specific tune, some new, some remixed from previous titles and will set the perfect mood for each stage and situation

- Gameplay - this is the major improvement over the last title.  They mixed the diversity and complexity of the 1st game with the quality of Risky's Boots and they managed to obtain a solid and lenghty game. When I completed the intro and saw that this game is composed of multiple islands (stages), I snapped my fingers and said to myself: this is promising. One hour later I was drooling at how awesome this is

CON's:
- If you want to gather all the hidden items, you will need to write the progress down a paper, because the game informs you of this only on the stage (island) select screen

- The inability to tweak the volume and customize the controls...hopefully these options will be implemented with a future patch

Final Thoughts:

Does it worth the full price? Yes! It's one of the few games that I bought it at a full price and didn't regret it. So, if you want a solid platformer, with awesome gameplay, characters and story...then don't look further.

15565311.review:
Well this is a huge step up from the previous title, Shantae: Risky's Revenge. This game take place after the events of Risky's Revenge, so if you haven't played it and don't want to be spoiled stop reading the review and go play it.

Shantae is trying to remain guardian of Scuttle Town as a full human with no genie magic. Risky come in and tell her that the Pirate Master is returning and they must band together to stop him. The story is nice and got some good developments/reveals for the side characters. I personally like Rotty Tops backstory in the game. It may not be an award winning story, but it good enough to keep you entertained to the end.

The gameplay is the same in the previous game. A side scrolling platform where you whip you're enemies into submissions. In place of the animal transformations from the last game, you will now use pirate items to help you progress through stages and defeat enemies. At the shop you can buy additional items and potions to help you along the way and upgrade your attacks and pirate gear for more damage. The gameplay is solid, no real fault that I encountered.

All in all the game plays like Risky's Revenge but with pirate weapons in place of animal transformation, but it longer which is good. If you read my Risky's Revenge review, I said the only downside was how short it was. This game is long enough to keep you entertained and got some backtracking in it if you want get 100%. 

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse kept me entertained to the end and left me wanting more. A good sequel and a must buy if you a fan of this series or just like 2D side scrolling platformers.

15557927.review:
Don't let those minimum specs discourage you from buying this. I'm running on a Intel HD Integrated Graphics card with an Intel Duel Pentium 2.13Ghz and it runs perfectly at 720p.

Anyway, this is the second Shantae game I played (the first being the original on the GBC) and I am really impressed. This game not only has great combat mechanics and metroidvania style exploration, but also brilliant dialogue. The first half of the game just doesn't take itself very seriously, and I love the game for that.

The art style is top-notch. Pixel-art is used for most of the game, with vectored character portraits being used in dialogue cutscenes.

Fan service and references to previous games are everywhere. [spoiler]I loved the hidden Dribble Fountain dungeon from the original game. :) Lol even Squid Baron makes a return as the midway filler boss that he was destined to be.[/spoiler]

The only problem I had with this game was a technical one. Half way through playing the game the graphics started to glitch out horribly. Restarting my computer fixed the issue though.

[strike]If you're going to play using a keyboard, be warned: the keys aren't rebindable, so I hope you love using the Arrow Keys for movement and ASDZXC for everything else![/strike]
Edit: Now the controls are rebindable thanks to an update!

10/10, I'm ret-2-go for 1/2 Genie Hero!

15551572.review:
Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is the third game in the Shantae series and takes place not long after Shantae: Risky's Revenge; and in my opinion, I think it's the best in the series. WayFoward has done a lot of improvements in each entry in the series and this game is no exception.

Pros:
- Story is pretty good
- Characters have much more depth now 
- Dialogue is charming and funny
- Less vague than the previous installments
- Graphics haven't improved much from Risky's Revenge but still look good
- Artstyle is very colorful and even better than Risky Revenge's
- Map is much much better than Risky's Revenge's map
- Runs better than Risky's Revenge on PC
- Pirate Gear is just as fun to use as the transformations from the previous games
- Longer than Risky's Revenge and packed in with lots of content
- Excellent soundtrack
- Dungeons are well designed
- Pretty solid controls
- Lots of replay value 


Cons:
- Only way to check how many dark magic and squid hearts you actually collected in a level is by going to the boat travel screen


If you enjoyed the previous Shantae games and platformers, then I highly recommend this game.

15543695.review:
As of this point where I am writing the review, I've only played up to just after the first Cracklebat fight and I have to say, it feels so good playing this game on Steam after 100% completing Pirate's Curse on the Wii U. It plays exactly like it does there, but there are very minor port issues I have, though it's not enough to hamper my enjoyment of this version.

The port issues thus far I've noticed is:

1) The keyboard and controller bindings as of this moment cannot be changed or edited. It is a very minor issue, but I do usually like to customize my keybindings to something I find more comfortable, especially on the keyboard. The default bindings are a bit odd for the keyboard; being one of those sets that use the arrow keys for movement & ZXC/ASD for general action input like a game from the 90's would have instead of having WASD for movement & JKL/UIO for action input.
(Port issue has been fixed!)

2) During the opening level, the screen would continuously shake & quiver. It may have been the explosions of the buildings that shook the screen, but it seems to last longer then in the Wii U version, even after the explosion sounds stop. It does however eventually stop, but I thought it would be something to mention. Nothing that bad, just a bit odd.
(Port issue has been fixed!)

So those are my opening thoughts on the Steam port for Pirate's Curse; one of the best games I've ever played on the Wii U, and now, despite than the minor port issues I mentions above, one of my favorite games on Steam; and featuring one of the most charming and adorable videogame characters you will ever go adventuring with.

Oh, man, where to start...
I love the Shantae series. Big fan since the first game, and it just gets better and better. Pirate's Curse stays true to the controls and platform gameplay of the first two games, but includes new ways to attack and navigate. Shantae can no longer transform, but the items she finds in her adventure feel just as natural as her transformations.
The enemies are a combination of those from part 1 and 2 plus new ones.
And the music, oh god, the music. Jake Kaufman, composer for the previous parts of the series, as well as Shovel Knight and Double Dragon Neon, is again responsible for it, and it is awesome. Fans of the earlier Shantae adventures will even get some familiar tunes.

15530257.review:
These are the pros and cons I have come up with during my first full (100%) playthrough of this game

+ I have never taken so many screenshots in a single game before 
+ Platforming
+ Artwork 
+ Soundtrack
+ Plot (not just the story...)
+ Humour in almost every cutscene
+ Death barriers are clearly marked so you know which holes are hidden rooms and which aren't
+ Lots of achievements
+ Didn't feel like I was missing too much backstory even though I have yet to play the previous two games in the series


- Two of the three combat skills you can buy are basically useless compared to your standard moveset
- Maps do not tell you which items you have already found (and where they were located) which can lead to excessive backtracking
- All the achievements are making my OCD kick in


All achievements acquired update:

+ The speed run achievements are quite the challenge and the game rewards you with two "fan-service-y" wallpapers if you can beat it in under 2 hours with any% and under 3 hours with 100% completion. 


Completed and acquired all achievements for Shantae: Risky's Revenge update:

Pirate's Curse vs Risky's Revenge 

+ More bosses 
+ More dungeons
+ Less confusing map system
+ Risky's ship and pirate flares replace Warp Squids (much more convenient travel than before)
+ Twice as long to complete (not counting Pirate Mode)
+ Movements and attacks are faster and more fluid
+ More meaningful dialogue and story
+ Artwork of characters has improved and looks more like a visual novel during dialogue
+ Save files now display %completion and location of last save
+ Different attacks do different amounts of damage instead of them all being considered one "hit"
+ Better quality and more memorable music (the soundtrack is also twice as long)
+ Graphics settings now allow true fullscreen (no black bars or stretch) for 1080p monitors

+/- Graphics are more or less the same as Risky's Revenge
+/- Weapons and items replace transformations and magic  (I personally like this game mechanic but some people would prefer the hallmark transformations of the previous Shantae games)


Shantae (GBC) 100% complete update

Its kind of funny how I ended up playing this series in reverse order... Now on to the update:

Pirate's Curse has many references to the original GBC game. Many of the songs heard in this game are actually remastered from the old chiptunes of Shantae. While the original game was MUCH more difficult in terms of travel from one area to the next, I feel like Pirate's Curse was a nice change from most of your troubles being day travel (or rather NIGHT travel when enemies were twice as tough) to more emphasis on labrinths, quests, bosses, and overall story.  I still think Shantae is one of the best GBC games out there so don't discount it just because I said Pirate's Curse is better. If you ever do get a chance, play Shantae (GBC). 

Verdict: Buy it now out of 10

15518499.review:
I bought this game for the story and comedy. Yup. I totally did not buy this game just for the fan-service. That's right, just for the story. That round, voluptuous story.

Edit 4-26-15
Now that I've beaten the game, I believe it's time I gave it a proper review.

Difficulty: 8/10 
The game is not too easy, and not too difficult. The puzzles are challenging, sometimes needing you to think outside the box to accomplish it. The enemies are well placed in the stages, preventing you from mindlessly steam-rolling through the stage. There are a lot of secret areas too, which rewards you greatly if you find them. The bosses are fun to go against, each requiring their own strategy to beaten. Plus, they get faster as they near death, increasing the challenge.

Art: 10/10
The design of the characters are amazing. The way they're drawn, the personalities given to each character, the dialogue, it's quite astonishing.  (and maybe you might even add one or more of them to your waifu collection). The enemy art is also great. 

Music:10/10
Each piece of music is a magnificent work of art. It meshes well with the stages their associated with. I recommend playing earphones, even if the game doesn't.

OVERALL: 9.5/10
If you're interested in challenging platformers, quirky characters, great music, and a memorable experience, this game is for you.

15511286.review:
(Note: I fully completed this game on the Wii U, so I have the experience to write a review)

Shantae and the Pirate's Curse is a 2D Metroidvania Style Platformer with a little bit of RPG sprinkled in. The game takes place after Risky's Revenge. There's a spirit of a once evil pirate called the Pirate Master. His spirit awakens to find out he's capable of taking over Sequin Land, and tries to spread the area with Dark Magic, effectively ruling it slowly but surely. It's up to Shantae, paired up with Risky Boots, to stop the Pirate Master by going to multiple islands and taking out the areas where he's getting his power.

This game is SO much better than Risky's Revenge ever hopes to be. It has a much faster pace overall, so it never feels sluggish. Shantae's attack, movement speed, and even the gameplay itself is generally quick, making killing enemies much less slow and tedious, and making the game overall a better, more paced experience. Other than that, it also has a much more interesting story with tons of character dialog and more immersive character development with funny and witty humor.

You aren't limited to one huge area like in Risky's Revenge, but you now have multiple islands to explore, each with their own individual theme and secrets to uncover; also their own dungeon. It certainly brings a breath of fresh air very often with each of the island's own unique style of puzzles, platforming, and fights. Pretty much makes the game itself very diverse so nothing is boring.

Shantae can no longer dance, but find some of Risky's pirate gear so she is granted more abilites. For example, she can find Risky's hat to have herself gently float downwards or use wind to go up, or Risky's pistol to solve puzzles and shoot enemies from afar. You'll find a new item in each dungeon, and they are well worth the journey to get them. Of course, it also makes the puzzles much more varied

The game is a little more on the RPG side this time around. Shantae's hair and Risky's weapons can be upgraded, and Shantae can even learn some new moves. It takes lots of money to get everything fully upgraded, so spend your gems wisely. It doesn't sound like much, but it's actually alot to upgrade. There's also healing items that enemies drop, and sometimes even attack items. You can access all of that by simply going to the item menu and using it, easy peasy.

Overall, this game is wonderful, and a FANTASTIC step up from Risky's Revenge. If you can get this, get it. It's a wonderful platformer series that has a great, memorable story, and fun, fast gameplay.

9/10

15508761.review:
This game is spectacular. 

If you enjoy platforming games you owe it to yourself to try this one out, either on the Wii U or on my personal preference here on steam.

The art style is vibrant, colorful and full of life, as are the environments, characters and Shantae herself. The dungeons and various islands are crafted to challenge your mind and creativity, while offering a wide variety of completely different enemies that don't hesitate to engage you. 

As you progress you're granted new items that introduce unique facets to the gameplay. One delicious layer of cake after another, the sweet saccharine icing of course being the tight, responsive controls that let you play exactly how you need. 

The plot is immediately engaging, and the music really psyches me up. If you were put off by the brevity in the prequel "Risky's Revenge" then you have nothing to fear. There's a huge supply of content in this sizable, well-polished package. 

phrasing

15508641.review:
Risky's Revenge review: http://steamcommunity.com/id/stumperman/recommended/277890/

This game is good, and should be bought.

Pros:
- Better and kind of worse item system. You are no longer trying to double tap the bottom screen of the 3DS to use an item. Instead you hit Select or whatever the keyboard control and press A on the item. The downside to this is the key items and map are also here, mainly the map. In the 3DS version you could have the map on the bottom, now you have to hit select then go to the map menu. I already beaten the game 7 times now so I don't need the map.

- Better than both prequels. WayForward know how to make good sequels and this out of all 3 shantae games is so far my favorite. Longer story. fair gameplay, not too easy not too hard, it does get harder as you progress etc etc.

- Good story
- Memorable Characters (nameless npcs are even memorable)
- Good Characters (I love all characters, even nameless npcs)
- Challenging but not impossible 
- Excelent Platforming + Puzzles
- Funny and unique dialouge.
- Wonderful sprite animation
- Awesome soundtrack
- High replay value (After beating the steam version 3 different times I will have beaten this 10 times)

Cons:

- Bad for players who do not have a thrill for adventure. This game does not exactly tell you what you have to do and where to do it. You have to use your brain and the tiny amount of hints the game gives to find out where things are. This is however good cause what's an adventure platformer if the game just tells you what to do and how to do it.

- Grinding Gems to get items. The items for upgrades and moves can be way too expensive and useless. Like I said I beat this game a lot of times, I never used the back kick move, or the back dash. Back dash being 100 gems (not bad) and the back kick being 400 which is too much for something I never had to use. Also you have to upgrade your hair strength, whip speed, scimitar, and pistol 3 times which adds up to a lot of gems. It's not that bad to grind for them but it could of been done better.

So if you like Metroid/Castlevenia you will love this game. The story in this one is more deep than Risky's Revenge and the original GBC game. It is totally worth the 20 dollars to get. 

That concludes this review with the 2 minor cons (one being really minor), I still have to give this game a wonderful score.

I give this game a 10/10

39450509.review:
Rating: 8/10
Genre: 2d Action/Platformer

The Good:
+ Good mix of platforming and combat 
+ Level design is well done often encouraging exploration
+ Collecting new items allows you to revisit previous areas and collect new things.  
+ Fun yet easy boss battles 
+ Witty dialogue 

The Average:
+/- A bit on the easy side for this type of game.  Other than the last dungeon, there aren’t a lot of difficult sections. Those looking for a more challenging game will not find it here. 

+/- Sometimes it can be difficult to figure out where to go next 

+/- Some needless backtracking that feels like padding to make the game longer 

Conclusion 
I can see why this game was getting high praise on Steam. This is a great game in the genre that is well designed in all aspects. Although some are saying this game is similar to Metroidvania type games, I found that is not the case at all; this game is broken into multiple levels.
